This morning, I commenced my second read of "We the Living,â€ a book by noted writer Ayn Rand that youâ€™ll find to be an existential wake-up call. Set in the grim reality of post-revolutionary Russia, it follows Kira Argounova, a fierce young woman fighting tooth and nail to live life on her terms amidst the suffocating grip of Soviet communism. Rand's first novel is a raw, unfiltered look at what happens when a government puts the power elite above the everyday individual. Itâ€™s a story that offers a searing indictment of how totalitarian regimes crush human spirit and creativity. Kiraâ€™s defiance is a blazing torch in the dark, a reminder of the power of the individual against the monolith of the state. Fast forward to todayâ€™s America, and you canâ€™t help but feel a chill down your spine. The themes in "We the Living" are more relevant than ever, echoing ominously in our current climate. Look around â€“ polarization is off the charts, surveillance is tightening, and free speech is under siege. Randâ€™s narrative is a flashing red light, warning us of the creeping encroachment of totalitarian ideologies. The novelâ€™s depiction of life under a regime that demands conformity and suppresses dissent should make us all sit up and take notice. The erosion of freedoms starts subtly, but if left unchecked, it can lead to a full-blown loss of autonomy and self-determination. Reading "We the Living" is essential if we want to grasp the existential threat of totalitarianism and authoritarianism lurking in America today. Rand doesnâ€™t just tell a story â€“ she screams a sobering warning like a howling jackal. The novelâ€™s stark portrayal of a society where the state dictates every move is a gut punch, reminding us whatâ€™s at stake when power concentrates in the hands of a few. Folks, we need to wake up and smell the authoritarian coffee. This book is a call to arms for defending our freedoms and standing firm against authoritarian overreach. By diving into this raw and powerful narrative, we can reignite our commitment to preserving a free and open society before itâ€™s too late. Stay tuned for my full review of Randâ€™s book and message in coming weeks by subscribing to my â€œGreat Books, Great Mindsâ€ digital newsletter, a link of which is provided in my profile. #authoritarian #democracy

"I face up to death but then I flip back into denial. Surely that's what it's like? I lie in bed in the small hours of the morning, absolutely terrified by the apprehension of my own dissolution...And then I go to sleep and wake up the morning and make toast.â€ - Will Self. I penned a few thoughts on dissonance this morning, and also explained why I prefer not to include the adjective 'cognitive'. The post was prompted by an image from Gaza, in which it appears both bombs and aid packages are falling from the sky. But the issue is not Gaza-specific. I believe we are living in an age of dissonance. What dissonance highlights that concepts like alienation, false consciousness and dislocation do not is the idea that our experience is defined by a lack or loss of agreement, *the sense that things that should fit together do not*. Our maps do not describe our territory. Dissonance is a relational idea at its heart, but the relationship in question is the most fundamental relationship of all, between the subject of experience and the object of inquiry; between ourselves and the world. In evolutionary theory, the Darwinian expression â€˜survival of the fittestâ€™ is often misunderstood to mean the survival of *the most fit*, as if it was about carrying the most coconuts or outrunning the fastest tigers. But the theory is really about the survival of *the most fitting*; those who survive are those whose physical traits, mental models and patterns of cooperation combine to best fit their context, niche or milieu, and who are protean enough to adapt to changes in those environments through heightened awareness and skilful sense-making. In the 21st century, our species will struggle to survive because it will struggle to fit. Perhaps the most pervasive source of dissonance arises in those who enjoy day-to-day life, know that the world has made extraordinary progress, and want to carry on with life as it is, and yet sense that everything has to change, and probably will. I share the following on technological dissonance, as a central feature of our time: "Technology should be a force for good, but we donâ€™t live in a world of wise elders who release it gradually to keep pace with our maturity as a species. Dissonance arises from the desire to believe in technology as a shared human endeavour for the greater good, while knowing that most world-changing technologies are injected into societyâ€™s bloodstream by commercially motivated private actors conducting simultaneous unsupervised experiments on a planetary scale." I think widespread dissonance is a sign that the world is becoming less intelligible. I also believe Jean Gebser's prophetic vision of the mental/rational function entering its 'deficient phase' feels truer than ever. The full reflection is here: https://lnkd.in/eQCfDdx9 ğŸ™ JR

Future Crunch put language around what I've been feeling this week. On one hand, women's leadership, inclusive leadership and social innovations programs are moving forward, Claudia Goldin wins the Nobel Prize in economics because of her work on women's economics. This is what if feels like to be in hope. Possibility. But Israel and Palestine? "The news is a lot right now. Israel is still reeling from the deadliest single day in its 75-year history, an indiscriminate massacre that killed over a thousand civilians in the most brutal manner imaginable. Two million people are now under siege in Gaza without food, water, medicine or power, and over a thousand are already dead. The horror of it all is compounded by the collective fear of what might yet be to come. Cynicism is easy because you're never wrong. If you keep on insisting the world is an awful place, and that it's only going to get worse, eventually a week like this comes along and proves you right. There was talk of peace in recent months, hope that something was changing. Overnight, that's been replaced by despair, and the familiar moral darkness that seems to hang so heavily over this part of the world. In the choice between barbarism and civilisation nobody should waffle, but what the past few days have also revealed is that a lot of people will mourn for dead Israeli civilians but not dead Palestinian ones, and a lot of people will mourn for dead Palestinian civilians but not dead Israeli ones. What has happened to our collective humanity? In times like this it feels strange to be writing a newsletter that celebrates progress. Disrespectful even. This is not a kumbaya though. Our aim isn't to say "Look over here! There's good stuff too!" Suffering isn't relative, there's no Benthamesque, cosmic scale weighing things up and pronouncing its verdict on world events. There are moments when the world feels like it hangs by a thread. This is one of them. We're feeling it intensely too, that sense of worry and fear. This week, our goal is just to stop you from going numb. The global media is chasing ambulances right now, and some point it's going to become too much. When you feel that, try to remember there's a big planet out there, and a lot of other stories surrounding the Israel-Gaza one. People in power on both sides want war. But they donâ€™t speak for all. What we can do is keep showing up with our attention and our humanity. Don't switch off, stay with it." We are stronger together. Thank you, Future Crunch.

The book I want everyone to read: Naomi Klein, whoâ€™s written well-known tracts on climate change and the insane and psychopathic system that is capitalism, has just published another important and surprisingly beautiful book. Itâ€™s called DoppelgÃ¤nger: A Trip into the Mirror World, and it investigates the political and social strangeness that covid unleashed. I read it in a whirl over the last two days, and thereâ€™s so much in it, but these are first thoughts on what landed strongly for me. Her book reminded me of the hope that came along with the virus; that it could be a reset (donâ€™t go back to normal! - remember that?). The hope that we could all come together to cooperate on big, complex global issues that would require sacrifice for transformation. The excitement galvanised in all working together to meet a threat, working together in the service of the vulnerable. But it wasnâ€™t long before that fractured, and suspicion crept in, and a sense of unity faded. And with it, my hopes for a real response to the far bigger issues approaching us fell. I know I canâ€™t know what large, collective steps could truly work to save what we love. But I do know how small, collective work is changing me, and for that I am deeply grateful. And itâ€™s here where, for me, DoppelgÃ¤nger is such a profound read, with topics close to my passions and my work. The concept of the DoppelgÃ¤nger - the secret double, the shadow, the one who carries all that we disown - is explored in a shattering, stunning way. There are many ways a culture hides what it cannot face, or is captured by unconsciousness. So Iâ€™m moved that she writes extensively about Indigenous dispossession of land and attempts at cultural annihilation, and her feeling that these facts are haunting contemporary culture, revealing themselves in the fantastical stories conspiracy communities create. Conspiracies are always telling some kind of truth. This is why it is important to give space and respect for all voices - hidden, shadowed things will be revealed. They can show us how to use the past - to understand what has been lost, and how we might integrate what we have repressed. I'm grateful I am that such a thoughtful, intelligent person has woven together many of the big questions Iâ€™ve been grappling with, and brought some sort of clarity to the complexity of the last few years. In the mix of the year-long course weâ€™ll be beginning soon, I am excited to be including this book as suggested reading. Here's the author's Amazon profile: https://lnkd.in/g3JdXdj7 Here's the book description: In a rural Michigan town, in a post-Covid world on the brink of a new disaster, Louie discovers an extraordinary abilityâ€”he canâ€™t die. Fortuitous, if not for the small catch that he doesnâ€™t want to live. While everyone else is desperately fighting to survive a global biotic crisis, Louie constantly seeks death only to be resurrected time and time again. Louie is the town nothing. If life was a school yard pick, he would be the last one on the team. Immortality is a burden, a cruel twist of fate, even as he wonders why him and what is he meant to do. But everything changes when Louie meets Katherine, a smart New York City woman determined to survive in this post-apocalyptic world. Finally, Louie has a reason to live, which is good timing because with each death he becomes weaker. It would be a love story if not for all the death and dying. Katherine and Louie arenâ€™t living in utopia. There are other survivors who have their own ideas about the future. Ones theyâ€™re willing to kill for. Louie and Katherine must not only defend themselves and their resources from outsiders but fight against their own darker natures before Louieâ€™s strange gift fades away. Amidst the chaos and despair, their story is one of hope, resilience, and redemption. Louie and Katherine, an unlikely modern-day Adam and Eve, will prove that even in the darkest of times, an ending can be a new beginning. Content Advisory: This book contains adult themes and explores the darker nature of the human condition. Readers will be exposed to content they may find upsetting, controversial, or offensive, including fictional portrayal of self-harm, suicide, and suicidal thinking.

I want to cover an in-depth analysis of #bullshit. Bullshit isn't lying, its UNRELATED to truth. Understanding bullshit, is to really understand truth. This is a brilliant book. It's improved my science, business practices, meditation, and personal relationships. I've returned to it again and again over the years and each time I've discovered something new about how I was deceiving myself or other people. Barry Silverberg, a nonprofit expert gave it to me years ago when I founded my first nonprofit. He said it was the only thing I really needed to know about charities. Not in an unkind way, in a "get this right" kind of way. And its one piece of advice I profoundly appreciate years later. I think of #charities like #innovation for #government. They handle social problems governments haven't prepared to handle yet or missed. In that capacity, they are very similar to #startups and now #climate industries. Innovation involves uncertainty, and a lot of people respond to uncertainty with vague feelings of unease, and concealment in the form of bullshit. We all do it. Bullshit I mean. And once I realized what IT was, not lying but really avoiding clarification, it helped me a lot with gaining people's trust and being more productive in my personal life and relationships. It's fine to bullshit, as long as everyone knows you're bullshitting. Tall tales, myths, joking, all the things we do with our friends that allow us to let down our hair and creatively wander can open up creative insights and crack us up. But we need to have conscious control over bullshitting. Climate people don't bullshit on purpose, they bullshit by DEFAULT. We don't know what we're doing yet, there are no real experts, all our systems are built for extraction, and we made some real mistakes when we hurt Indigenous Peoples. Honestly, nothing we're doing now is truly working that well. And understanding that makes it a lot easier to be compassionate about problems. It's embarrassing and shameful to admit that the emperor has no clothes and you're a little bit lost. But it's also really freeing.
